conclusion: Principles of shadow formation and effects of changing light source position are needed to determine shadow changes.
Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, and their shape and size depend on the object shape and light source position.
The size of the shadow is influenced by the angle of light rays relative to the object.
The light source is currently at a certain height, casting shadows of the objects on the ground.
When the light source moves upward, the angle of light rays relative to the objects decreases.
The change in angle affects the size and position of the shadows.
As the light source moves upward, the shadows will become smaller due to more parallel light rays reducing shadow spread.
The shadows will move closer to the objects because the light rays are coming from a higher angle, causing less projection distance.
Shadow A (Apple) will become smaller and move closer to the apple.
Shadow B (Paper) will become smaller and move closer to the paper.
Shadow C (Glass) will become smaller and move closer to the glass.
Shadow D (Drumstick) will become smaller and move closer to the drumstick.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will become smaller and move closer to their respective objects when the light source moves upward.
